column15: In the N.E. part of the district this is pronounced aim.
In the N.E. part of the district this is pronounced aim.
See shím.
In the S.W. part of the district this is pronounced chín.
A distinction is made in the tones of this word when used ns a Noun or a Verb. In the latter case it is 下入; in the former 中入.

In the N.E. part 州 is pronounced the same as in Cantonese, but 州 in the S.W. is pronounced chíú, and with some of the other characters in this class, if not all, the pronuncia tion is such as given above.
The most of these words under ch‘i in Cantonese, say two-thirds, are ch‘e in San-wúí; for the rest see chi and ch‘í.
There appears to be only one word under this heading. In the S.W. it is chím.
In the S.W. it is pronounced as above, or as ch‘ím.
But 折 is pronounced as in Canton.

Under this heading some take this pronunciation. But 炤, 昭, and 招 are chíú in San-wúí city and the N.E. and 兆 becomes sheu. One or two of the others, being used almost entirely in the book language, conform to the Cantonese. See ch‘íú and sheu.

column6: 會西南音，書面語音同廣州

column15: Under this heading some take this pronunciation. But 炤, 昭, and 招 are chíú in San-wúí city and the N.E. and 兆 becomes sheu. One or two of the others, being used almost entirely in the book language, conform to the Cantonese. See ch‘íú and sheu.
Roughly speaking the most of the characters in this class of words are pronounced as above. 抽 however, is ch‘áu in the S.W. and in some places ch‘eu, and 臭 in San-wúí city itself is ch'íú.
Some of these are ch‘e. See the note under that class.

Under this heading some of the words, the greater number, are pronounced as here, for instance 斟 and 枕 and with regard to one 針 it is called chim in the S.W., but at San-wúí city and in the N.E. it is chem (See that heading), while at least one word 箴 is chám and another one 砧 tem.

In the S.W. this is chem, but in the other parts of the district chím, or chem, or possibly only chím in the other places, With regard to 粘 at all events, it is in the S.W. chim, clty chem, and N.E. chím.
In the S.W. chen. Also in the word 戰 the some change takes place, being chen in the S.W. and chín elsewhere; some of the other less used words are chín however.
The same change occurs in the S.W. as in the last case, it being pronounced ch‘en.
This class is chep in the S.W.
倡 and 娼 have the same pronunciation, while 窗 is pronounced ts‘ong.
In pronouncing the word 處 the lips seem to be more closed as chúí.
捉 is pronounced chok.
21,22, and 23. These three classes are also pronounced in San-wúí city and N.E as chen (lst and 3rd), and ch‘en (2nd) respectlvely.
21,22, and 23. These three classes are also pronounced in San-wúí city and N.E as chen (lst and 3rd), and ch‘en (2nd) respectlvely.
21,22, and 23. These three classes are also pronounced in San-wúí city and N.E as chen (lst and 3rd), and ch‘en (2nd) respectlvely.
In the city it is also pronounced as ch‘et.
火 is pronounced fá in Kong-mún, as well as fe.
In S.W. pronounced fúí.
ln Kong-mún pronounced fá, or fe. See also ko.
The first class in the city and N.E. are pronounced faí, as well as fúí. Also note that 吠 though pronounced fúí in the book language is púí in the colloquial. In the 2nd class 賄 is pronounced hoí.
The second class is pronounced fen in the S. W. See also Wan.
In speaking of the south wind they say nám fung꜄, and of the north, pak fung꜅ sometimes, though more often pak fung꜄.
In speaking of salt shrimps, they say hám má instead of hám há, but this does not obtain in San-wúí city. See also Ts‘ui, and Ts‘ui.
痕 is, however, haí in the S.W., and háí in the city.
In the S W. pronounced also hat : meaning a seed, it is pronounced wút
This is t′aú as well, but generally as above.
Pronounced like hai in the English word hair. In the S.W. this is Heá. The sound is as if the English word hair were pronounced very slowly. In San-wúí city and N.E. it is hö. At Kong-mún it is hö.
Sometimes this is t'íp in this district of the country as well as at Canton. See Ying.
This is pronounced t′oí, but seldom.
This is also pronounced t‘ok sometimes.
See Kwé.
The better educated pronounce it as in Cantonese.

column15: 妗 becomes K‘em.
The 2nd class is pronounced as K‘wang, or K‘wáng as well.

Some of the words which come under the first class in Canton are, however, pronounced keu in the San-wúí Dialect, 九, and 狗 are keu, the latter is however pronounced kau in the S.W. part of the district.
求 is K‘eu in the S.W. In the city k‘íú generally.
See also Kwúí, and K‘wúí.
See Köng, No. 188 Note.
Pronounced kip as well in San-Wúí City, and kíp only in the N.E. of the District. See also Kwá, Note.
In the N.E. of the District pronounced kíp as well.
See also Káu, and Kwún.
The second class is pronounced kwún in the S.W.
This 2nd class is pronounced k‘ün in the S.W.
The i is sounded slightly broader than in Canton, very like if not.exactly the same as some people pronounce the English word king, i.e. somewhat as if it had a slight sound of the vowel e in it.
級 is pronounced k‘áp in the S.W.
The 2nd class is pronounced k‘üt in the S. W.
戈 is fo. 果 is pronounced by the better educated as kwo.
The latter class sometimes becomes kaí, mostly in the East part of the District. See No. 132.

歸 is kéí San-wúí city and the N.E. and kwúí in the S.W. See also Kwúí.

捐 and 眷 are kwún in the S.W. and kin in San-wúí city and N.E. Some of the 2nd Class are also pronounced ken by some in the S.W., as 官, and 館; only the well educated in that part of the district pronounce them properly. But 滾 is kwún in the W.S. In the city Kwan about the same as in Cantonese.
